sen.j: 黄丹袍（おうにのほう）とは皇太子が儀式の際に着用する束帯装束の袍のことである。
sen.e: Oni-no-ho is a term of wafuku (traditional Japanese clothes) that means a costume, called sokutai shozoku, which a crown prince puts on in a ritual.
"Oni no ho" is a ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the imperial court) of sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) costume, worn by a crown prince in the rituals.
sen.cmt: 原文「和服用語集」を「袍」に修正しました。英文全文修正しました。

sen.j: この名前はクチナシ（くちなし）とベニバナ（べにばな）で染めた色名「黄丹」からである。
sen.e: It was named after the color "Oni", which is obtained by dying a cloth with gardenia and safflower

tit.cmt: Brief history を History に修正しました。

sen.j: 黄丹は、『養老律令』の「衣服令」において皇太子の礼服（朝賀と即位に使う正装）・朝服（のちの束帯の原型）の「衣」の色と規定されている。
sen.e: According to "The Garment Code" of "Yoro Ritsuryo Code", oni was determined as the color of "koromo" (robe) of crown prince's reifuku (full dress to be used for choga (retainers' New Year greeting to the emperor) and the enthronement ceremony) and chofuku (the original model of sokutai).

According to 'The Garment Code' of "Yoro Ritsuryo Code," oni was determined as the color of 'koromo' (robe) of crown prince's reifuku (formal dress used for choga [retainers' New Year's greeting to the emperor] and the enthronement ceremony) and chofuku (the original model of sokutai).

sen.j: 天皇の黄櫨染御袍が中国の赭黄袍を起源として平安時代初期に導入された（それ以前の天皇の袍は白色であったと推定されている）のに対し、黄丹色の日本での起源は、より古い。
sen.e: While korozen-no-goho (a costume which an emperor puts on when he performs an important ritual), whose origin was shakoho of China, was imported in the early Heian period, oni-no-ho came to be in use in Japan earlier than that.

While korozen no goho (a costume which an emperor puts on when he performs an important ritual), whose origin was shakoho (apricot-yellow robe made for the exclusive use of an emperor) of China, was imported in the early Heian period, the origin of oni no ho is earlier than that.
sen.cmt: korozen-no-goho 及び oni-no-ho のハイフンを削除しました。shakoho に (apricot-yellow robe made for the exclusive use of an emperor) を追記しました。oni no ho came to be in use in Japan を the origin of oni no ho に修正しました。
sen.e: While korozen no goho (a costume which an emperor puts on when he performs an important ritual), whose origin was shakoho (apricot-yellow robe made for the exclusive use of an emperor) of China, was imported in the early Heian period, the origin of oni no ho is earlier than that.

sen.j: 平安時代前期には皇太子の礼服は赤色の九章服になったが（さらに朝賀の廃止された平安中期以降は、皇太子の礼服の着装例がない）、朝服においてはその後も使用され、文様も鴛鴦丸（えんおうまる）が使われることが一般化した。
sen.e: Although crown prince's reifuku was replaced by red-colored kushofuku in the early Heian period (after choga was abolished in the middle of Heian period, crown prince's reifuku fell into disuse), oni-no-ho was continuously used for chofuku and eno-maru (the design of mandarin duck making a circle) came to be in use for its pattern.

sen.e: Although the crown prince's reifuku was replaced by a red kushofuku in the early Heian period (after choga was abolished in the middle of the Heian period, the crown prince's reifuku fell into disuse), oni no ho was continuously used for chofuku and the use of the eno-maru (a design in which mandarin ducks form a circle) pattern became common practice.

sen.j: 室町時代に至り、立太子が中絶し、皇位継承者は親王のままで即位することが一般化すると、黄丹袍は中絶した。
sen.e: The use of oni-no-ho was suspended in the Muromachi period when the investiture ceremony of the Crown Prince was suspended and the heir to the Imperial Throne asscended the throne from the status of imperial prince.

sen.e: The use of oni no ho was suspended in the Muromachi period when the investiture ceremony of the Crown Prince was suspended and the heir to the Imperial Throne ascended the throne from the status of imperial prince.

sen.j: 江戸時代に至り、朝仁親王（東山天皇）の立太子以降皇太子の制度が復活する。
sen.e: The investiture ceremony of the Crown Prince was revived in the Edo period, starting with that of Imperial Prince Tomohito (the Emperor Higashiyama).

sen.j: しかし、当初は赤色袍と称して、赤茶色の袍をもちいることがあったらしく、裂が各所に現存している。
sen.e: However, it seems that a costume of reddish-brown color, called akairo-no-ho, was used in the beginning and its fabrics are existent at various places.

sen.j: なお皇太子の「赤色袍」は『台記』などにみえるが、黄丹の異名であったものか（黄丹に似たオレンジ色の検非違使の朱紱も平安中期以降は「赤衣」とよばれたという事実がある）、別のものであったものか不明である。

sen.j: 朝仁親王以来、紋は花形の枠に下向きになった鴛鴦（おしどり）一羽を収めた（鴛鴦とはいっても雄のみ）もので、定型化して現在まで変わっていない。
sen.e: The crest of a mandarin duck (only male) sitting inside the flower-shaped frame has been used since the time of Imperial Prince Tomohito.
Since the time of Imperial Prince Tomohito, the crest of a mandarin duck (only male) sitting inside the flower-shaped frame has been stylized and never changed till now.

sen.j: 近世後期の規定では、衣紋道（えもんどう）の山科家・高倉家ともに冬の場合、元服後の縫腋袍の仕立てのときは裏を黄平絹、元服前の闕腋袍の仕立てのときは裏を黄丹平絹の表裏同色とする。
sen.e: For winter-use ones, according to the regulations established in the late early-modern times by Yamashina family and Takakura family, families of emon-do (traditional technique for dressing up ceremonial costume), yellow hiraginu silk was used for lining in the case of hoeki-no-ho, the one that was used by an adult, while yellow tanpei silk was used for ketteki-no-ho, the one that was used by a minor.

According to the regulations in the late early-modern times, in winter, both Yamashina and Takakura families of emon-do (traditional technique for dressing up ceremonial costume) tailor a hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by the emperor and high-ranking officials) after coming of age with yellow hiraginu silk for lining, while tailoring a ketteki no ho (open sleeve seams outer robe) before coming of age with oni silk, same color as lining.

sen.j: 紋の配置は升目状に縦横一列に配して、普通の装束地のように一段ごとに紋の位置をずらすことはしない。
sen.e: The crests were lined up vertically and horizontally, and they were not staggered stepwise as the case of ordinary cloth of shozoku.
